title: The Ruth Finney Papers
extent: 6.4 linear feet contained in 4 boxes and 6 folio boxes.
shelf location: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Special Collections Department.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_biog: Western correspondent for the Scripps-Howard Newspaper Alliance; covered the Teapot Dome Oil scandal, monitored the passage of the Boulder Canyon Project Act, and investigated corruption in the electric and gas utilities industry. Nominated for the Pulitzer Prize in 1931.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_descrip: Materials relating to Finney's career as a newspaper reporter, including correspondence, scrapbooks, diaries, manuscripts, clippings, photographs, research materials, legal documents, and personal mementos. Also contains her unpublished autobiography, <cite>Journey From the Star</cite>, and her unpublished history of Downieville, California, <cite>Rogues and Riches</cite>.

contributing institution: University of California, Davis General Library, Dept. of Special Collections
title: Charles E. Schneeman, Jr. Papers
creator: Schneeman, Charles, 1912-1972
abstract: Contains artwork and correspondence of illustrator Charles E. Schneeman, Jr. The group of science fiction illustrations includes roughly 500 drawings, sketches, photochemical reproductions (including photographs used as reference for sketches), and paintings. The collection also includes a small collection of correspondence from such science fiction authors as Isaac Asimov.
physical location: Researchers should contact Special Collections to request collections, as many are stored offsite.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_biog: Illustrator/science fiction artist
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_descrip: Artwork and correspondence. The group of science fiction illustrations includes roughly 500 drawings, sketches and photomechanical reproductions as well as photographs used as reference for sketches as well as a small collection of correspondence from such science fiction authors as Isaac Asimov.

contributing institution: University of California, Davis Library, Dept. of Special Collections
title: Waddell F. Smith Papers
creator: Smith, Waddell F.
abstract: Waddell F. Smith, historian and collector, was the great grandson of William B. Waddell, member of freighting firm of Russell, Majors and Waddell, founders of Pony Express (1860). Smith retired from military service (1949) to devote time to study and promotion of Pony Express history. He settled in San Rafael, Calif. and organized a Pony Express History and Art Gallery. The Gallery became headquarters for the National Pony Express Centennial Association, of which Waddell Smith was President. In this capacity Smith organized and staged a reenactment of a Pony Express run (1960). He published "Stage Lines and Express Companies in California" (1965) and a number of pamphlets, such as "Pony Express versus Wells Fargo Express" (1966) The Papers contain the Pony Express Gallery Records as well as Smith's Pony Express scrapbook, research notes, writings and photographs.
physical location: Researchers should contact Special Collections to request collections, as many are stored offsite.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_biog: Historian, collector. Great grandson of William B. Waddell, member of freighting firm of Russell, Majors and Waddell, founders of Pony Express (1860). Smith retired from military service (1949) to devote time to study and promotion of Pony Express history. He settled in San Rafael, Calif. and organized a Pony Express History and Art Gallery.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_descrip: Social and business correspondence of Waddell Smith, financial records of Smith's Pony Express Museum, photographs, newspaper clippings, Pony Express memorabilia, and Overland Mail Centennial Association records.

title: The Joseph A. Baird, Jr. Collection
extent: 46 linear feet in 45 archives boxes and 2 folio boxes.
shelf location: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Special Collections Department.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_biog: Professor of Art, University of California, Davis (1953-1985). Curator and art consultant to the California Historical Society (1962-1963; 1967-1970), owner of the North Point Gallery in San Francisco.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_descrip: Research files covering 19th and 20th century painting, drawing, graphic art, sculpture, and architecture in California and Mexico, including exhibition catalogs, photographs, clippings, and research indexes of Californian artists; flyers and exhibition catalogs from public and private museums and art galleries around the world, including material describing the holdings of these places as well as of foundations and private collections.

title: Sherrill Halbert Papers,
creator: Halbert, Sherrill, 1901-
abstract: Sherrill Halbert, Sacramento jurist and amateur historian, served as a director of the Pony Express Centennial Association from 1958-1961. He was administrator of many Association Projects including the creation of trail markers and penned about twenty "Pony Express Days" vignettes. The collection consists of Halbert's own correspondence, speeches, and writings on the Pony Express. It also includes correspondence, clippings, maps, memorabilia and photographs pertaining to the activities of the Centennial Association.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_biog: Sacramento, California jurist, amateur historian. Halbert was a director of Pony Express Centennial Association (1957-1961). He was administrator of many Association projects including creation of trail markers.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_descrip: Halbert's correspondence, speeches, and writings on the Pony Express. The collection also contains clippings, maps, memorabilia, and photographs pertaining to the activities of the Pony Express Centennial Association.

contributing institution: University of California, Davis Library, Dept. of Special Collections
title: Eastman's Originals Collection
creator: Eastman, Jervie Henry, 1880-1969
abstract: Collection includes photographs, negatives, and postcards for a wide variety of northern California locations and events, including dam construction, logging, mining, food processing, and community buildings and activities.
physical location: Researchers should contact Archives and Special Collections to request collections, as many are stored offsite.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_biog: Jervie Henry Eastman was born, July 20, 1880, in White Cloud, Michigan. His family moved to northern California in 1886. In 1898, Eastman launched his photographic career in Sisson, California (later named Mount Shasta), as a view photographer. He became a partner in the Shasta View Company in 1907. Eastman lost his entire stock of plates and cards in a fire in 1912.In 1921, Jervie Henry Eastman moved to Susanville and established Eastman & Company as a commercial photography and post card studio. In 1936 he hired Mirl Simmons, a young photographer from Hillsborough, West Virginia, to help with the postcard photography. In 1947, Eastman and Simmons became partners. The business had expanded to provide photographic supplies to southeastern Oregon and studios in Westwood, Weed, and Susanville.Eastman retired from photography in 1959 and sold his share of the business to Simmons. He died in Susanville on February 11, 1969.Simmons ran the Eastman Studios until 1980, when he retired and sold the business to John and Shirley Castle. Mirl Simmons died on April 27, 1987, in Jamestown, California.The Eastman's Originals Collection (the historical postcards and negatives) was sold to Anne Fisher in 1982. She managed the collection until her retirement in 1994. She donated the collection to the University of California, Davis, in 1994.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_descrip: Photographs, negatives, and postcards for a wide variety of northern California locations and events, including dam construction, logging, mining, food processing, and community buildings and activities.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_moreinfo_name: Digitized images from this collection are available on Calisphere
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_moreinfo2_name: View digitized films from the Eastman's Originals Collection on the Internet Archive

title: Pony Express Centennial Association Records,
creator: Pony Express Centennial Association
abstract: The Pony Express Centennial Association was incorporated (1958) to foster and facilitate commemorations of the centennial of the Pony Express (1860-1861). The man principally responsible for promoting this Association was retired Air Force Lt. Col. Waddell Smith, a grandson of one of the partners in the firm Russell, Majors and Waddell which had operated the Pony Express. The Records of the Pony Express Centennial Association consist principally of the correspondence of Waddell Smith. The collection also contains financial records, reports, clippings, other materials Smith gathered and some correspondence of Edwin H. Burgess, Director of the Washington D.C. Branch of the Centennial Association.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_biog: Incorporated (1958) to commemorate Pony Express centennial (1860/61-1960/61). Widely promoted by Waddell Smith, descendant of an original partner, collector of Pony Express artifacts and authority on company history. President Eisenhower served as honorary chairman. Board of Directors included postmaster general and director of National Park Service.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_descrip: By-laws, Articles of Incorporation, and Directives of Association. Also contains Board of Directors minutes, official correspondence, financial records, special committee records, commemorative souvenirs, photographs, and news releases, and correspondence of vice chairman of Association, Edwin H. Burgess (1959-1976).

title: TOBY COLE ARCHIVES
shelf location: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Special Collections Department.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_biog: Theatrical-literary agent based in New York City from 1957 to 1976; among Cole's clients were Saul Bellow, Bertolt Brecht, Zero Mostel, Luigi Pirandello, and Sam Shepard.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_descrip: Business and financial records, correspondence, legal documents, photographs, programs, promotional materials, and scripts documenting Cole's activities.

title: The San Francisco Mime Troupe Archives
extent: 77.4 linear feet contained in 73 archive boxes, 16 folio boxes, 1 document case, and map case drawers.
author: Simon, Stacie
shelf location: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Special Collections Department.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_biog: Founded by Ronald G. Davis in 1959 and later reorganized as a collective, the San Francisco Mime Troupe is one of the oldest continuing radical theatre groups in the United States.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_descrip: Audio-visual materials, business records, correspondence, designs, ephemera, films, financial records, legal documents, photographs, promotional materials, and scripts; extensive documentation of the Troupe's activities during the 1960's and 1970's.

title: Displaced Homemakers Center Archives
shelf location: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Special Collections Department.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_biog: Located in Oakland, California, the Displaced Homemakers Center offered assistance in job training, education, and job placement to women who were suddenly forced into the job market due to the unavailability or incapacity of their spouse.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_descrip: Correspondence, business reports, forms, and publications.
Handwritten annotated ledger of rainfall totals in Visalia, California.
Correspondence between Wilson and several writers regarding publication endeavors.

title.rendered: Viticulture and Enology Collection: Wine Labels.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_descrip: Wine labels, primarily from California..

title.rendered: Viticulture and Enology Collection: United States Pamphlets.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_descrip: Promotional wine pamphlets from United States wineries, with a strong emphasis on California.
Posters and broadsides relating to wine-making and wineries, as well as advertising particular varieties.

acf.ucdlib_manuscript_biog: Professor of Mathematics and Surveying and Associate Statistician in the Experiment Station, University of California, College of Agriculture.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_descrip: Account of Titus Club hike to Mt. Whitney (1925), photograph, and Agricola yearbook (1916) dedicated to Titus.
Nineteenth and twentieth century American and European publications, including a sizable run of Playbill.

Programs, program clippings, pictorial clippings, newspaper clippings, promotional materials, and ticket stubs are included in many of the scrapbooks; others contain only pictorial clippings which depict costumed actors and actresses. Most items relate to early 20th century American theatre, but there are some nineteenth century items as well as British and French material.
Brochures, mailers, and press releases advertising upcoming and ongoing theatrical events, mostly in the United States.
Mostly 19th century advertisements for melodramatic productions..
Mostly 20th century advertisements and artwork, including festivals and alternative theatre groups.
Books, catalogs, and pamphlets for theatrical equipment; clippings, correspondence, financial records, legal documents, promotional materials, realia..
Depictions of actors in character roles, primarily English actors in Shakespearean roles.
Set and costume designs by Henri Bodart, Dany, Endre, Erte, Roger Furse, Thomas Heselwood, Josef Platzer, Lorenzo Sacchetti, and Zig, among others.

Pictorial clippings showing actors (mostly American) as themselves or in prominent roles; program clippings giving the dramatis personae of a particular production; articles and reviews pertaining to specific productions; obituaries of actors, dancers, musicians, and other performing arts personalities.

Music & lyrics for songs from films, musicals, and theatre.The sheet music in this collection has been cataloged individually in the Harvest Library catalog. To find the sheet music, search in Harvest author = Sheet Music Collection. A quick link to that search is provided below as "Search Harvest Catalog."

acf.ucdlib_manuscript_biog: Author of The Wine Press and the Cellar: A Manual for theWine-maker and the Cellar-man.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_descrip: Scrapbook containing clippings on wine, brandy, raisins,and grapes as well as Rixford's handwritten notes.
Pamphlets concerning the role of the Christian church in rural farming communities, including papers published by the National Catholic Rural Life Conference.
Early manuscript draft of a book Raynesford co-authored with Wayne C. Lee, <cite>Trails of the Smoky Hill: From Coronado to the cowtowns</cite> (1980).
Bumper stickers, buttons, flyers, ballot tickets, about half late 19th century, half mid-20th century. Local, state, and national levels of government represented.

acf.ucdlib_manuscript_biog: Early Native American comedian noted for his polished acting in Old comedy and for his dialect and broken-English parts; member of the Park Theatre, New York, stock company.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_descrip: Seventeen signed working scripts once the property of Henry Placide.

acf.ucdlib_manuscript_biog: Cotton farmer in Tulare County, California, and one of the leaders in the revolt against the one-variety law for farming cotton.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_descrip: Correspondence and reports relating to cotton farming.

title.rendered: Pacific Coast Association of Nurserymen Collection.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_descrip: Proceedings of the 10th-13th annual meetings.

title.rendered: Our Lady of Vladimir Convent Collection.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_biog: Russian Orthodox convent, located in San Francisco.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_descrip: Photograph album depicting life in the convent.

acf.ucdlib_manuscript_biog: O'Higgins, also known as the Marquis of Osorno, was an influential Chilean political leader the late 18th century.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_descrip: Correspondence with church and governmental figures regarding missions, road repair, land allocation, military strength, and provisions for the poor.

acf.ucdlib_manuscript_biog: Thoroughbred horse-racing club based in Oakland, California in the early 20th century.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_descrip: Official programs of the club.
Published and unpublished materials relating to arguments for and against the prohibition of alcohol, including the responses of individual states and organizations.

Manuscript paper written under the auspices of the National Defense Research Committee for the Office of Scientific Research and Development, entitled A survey of rationing and subsistence in the United States Army 1775 to 1940, the final report on Troop feeding programs, written by Samuel C. Prescott, former Dean of Science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
Letters in German and French regarding the Bordeaux trade.

acf.ucdlib_manuscript_biog: Founded in 1898, the Moscow Art Theatre opened with Tolstoy's <cite>Tsar Feodor Ivanovich</cite>. This theatre was the first to successfully produce Chekhov's plays, and between 1898 and 1904 it performed <cite>The seagull</cite>, <cite>Uncle Vanya</cite>, <cite>The three sisters</cite>, and <cite>The cherry orchard</cite>, the plays upon which Chekhov's reputation primarily rests.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_descrip: Sixty-two reproductions from photographs of early Moscow Art Theatre productions.

title.rendered: Morris, Jane. Letters to Theodore Watts-Dunton.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_biog: Jane Burden (1839-1914) was married to William Morris (1834-1896), an English poet and the author of <cite>The waters of the wondrous isles</cite> (1897).
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_descrip: Letters written by Morris to Theodore Watts-Dunton, primarily regarding travel accommodations.

acf.ucdlib_manuscript_biog: Born in Edinburgh, Scotland, actress and journalist Moffat made her first stage appearance at the Savoy Theater, New York. She became editor of the woman's page of the <cite>New York evening mail</cite> for two years, then returned to the stage. She made her first stage appearance in London at the Royalty in 1911.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_descrip: Program, newspaper clipping, and script with scene plot, and production photographs, all relating to the play <cite>Just like a woman</cite>.

acf.ucdlib_manuscript_biog: American scenic designer and originator of what theatre historian Oscar Brockett described as "theatricalized realism."
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_descrip: Set designs: eight 4" x 3" original sketches executed on drafting paper in watercolor, gouache, and pencil depicting stage sets for the musical Mata Hari, which opened at the National Theatre, Washington, D.C., on 18 November 1967.
Manuscript of Mexican land grant.
Two cassette tapes of Joanna and Michael McClure reading their poetry at the University of California, Davis.

acf.ucdlib_manuscript_biog: Professor of Economics, University of California, Davis.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_descrip: Transcripts and tapes of interviews for Mayer's book, <cite>Monetary policy and the great inflation in the United States: the Federal Reserve and the failure of macroeconomic policy, 1965-1979</cite>.

acf.ucdlib_manuscript_biog: Agricultural Experiment Station chemist and Professor of Food Science and Technology, University of California, Davis; co-author of <cite>Wine Making at Home</cite> (1962).
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_descrip: Affidavits, correspondence, research notes and reports regarding enology methods.
Court records and correspondence concerning the patent dispute between John Manny and Cyrus McCormick over a reaper invention.

acf.ucdlib_manuscript_biog: Ph.D., University of California, Davis, Parasitology; University Extension Parasitologist, University of California, Davis; author of <cite>The ticks of California</cite> (1984).
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_descrip: Extension leaflets written by Loomis pertaining to parasites in horses and turkeys; Cooperative Extension newsletter: Entomology and Parasite Notes.

title.rendered: Lee, William H. Oral History Recording.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_biog: William H. Lee, an African American civic leader, co-founded the Sacramento Observer newspaper.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_descrip: The collection contains a video interview of Lee conducted by Ginger Rutland.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_moreinfo_name: The recording is available on YouTube here.

acf.ucdlib_manuscript_descrip: Agriculture club notebook regarding constitution, by-laws, meetings, and membership from 1871 to 1873.

acf.ucdlib_manuscript_biog: John S. Dunn (1810-1885) lived in the Nevada City, California area.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_descrip: Two letters from Dunn addressed to "Brother," two receipts, and an agreement between Dunn, Charles Dunn Jr., and Richard Rowe regarding mining claims on Kennebec Hill in Nevada County, California.

acf.ucdlib_manuscript_biog: Chief of Market Organization and Costs, U.S. Department of Agriculture (1948-1958); Professor of Agricultural Economics, University of California, Davis.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_descrip: Notes and correspondence regarding Deloach's Fulbright and honorary doctoral degree from the University of Newcastle upon Tyne in 1964.

Clippings, photographs, promotional materials, and souvenir programs pertaining to dance in the United States and abroad. Ballet companies represented in this collection include Ballet Russe, American Ballet Theatre, Royal Danish Ballet, San Francisco Ballet, Sadler's Wells Ballet, Leningrad Kirov Ballet, Bolshoi Ballet, and Stuttgart Ballet.

acf.ucdlib_manuscript_biog: Capay Valley physician
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_descrip: Diaries which discuss a medical doctor's visits, prescriptions and accounts.

acf.ucdlib_manuscript_biog: John Cleveland's family were neighbors of the parents of Horace Greeley. After learning the printer's trade, he obtained a place on the <cite>New York Tribune</cite>, which had been founded by Greeley three years before. In 1846 he married Mr. Greeley's sister Esther. He was at different times Albany correspondent of the <cite>Tribune</cite>, editor of the weekly and semi-weekly editions, and news editor.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_descrip: Letters from Horace Greeley to Cleveland.

acf.ucdlib_manuscript_biog: Chief Scientific Illustrator for the Bureau of Entomology, USDA; Senior Scientific Illustrator at the University of California, Davis.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_descrip: Ten botanical lithographs. For examples of Benson's entomological illustrations, see the Howard Lester McKenzie Collection (D-309).

acf.ucdlib_manuscript_biog: American stage manager, producer, and playwright known for his realistic stage sets.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_descrip: Thirty-three photographs depicting Belasco's production of <cite>The Darling of the Gods</cite>, which opened December 3, 1902, at the Belasco Theatre in New York City.
Graphic announcements of Avant-Garde poetry events.
Advertisements for book fairs, poetry readings, and other public events; press releases announcing new books and printing services.
Seven bills of sale and transfer of African slaves in New England.

acf.ucdlib_manuscript_biog: Professor of Mathematics, University of California, Davis.
acf.ucdlib_manuscript_descrip: Extensive collection of sheet music for piano, with an emphasis on sentimental music from the turn of the century; some research and classroom materials in mathematics theory and philosophy.
Paper written by Allred entitled George Morgan, pioneer importer and breeder of American Herefords (1967), detailing Morgan's family history and the development of his business.
